I remember when our physics teacher wrote F=ma on the board, we all asked him why, but he didn't explain it, he said "it just is", so we all said "So it's magic sir? Sir is it magic sir? It just is sir".

I think it's difficult to explain that the idea of a 'Newton' is man made, and defined by the natural properties of acceleration and mass, not the other way round. Therefore, of course F=ma, because a Newton is defined as the force required to accelerate 1kg of mass by 1 m/s^-2.

It's also important to emphasise that even though the idea of a Newton isn't a natural 'thing' like mas or acceleration, it doesn't mean it's not useful to use it. We don't live in 4 spatial dimensions, yet we use 4-dimensional numbers to rotate objects in 3-D space: the 4th spatial dimension doesn't exist, as far as we know, yet we can use it, just like multiplying arbitrary numbers together to form a Newton is still useful.

I wish my teacher had told us something similar instead of just telling us the definition of a Newton, which just seemed very arbitrary.

"two and a half tons of Inertia" - that's not the unit to use in this case. What matters is the moment of inertia, and that has units of kg m^2. It's not just the mass, but also how it's distributed about the axis of rotation.

A little bit of calculation, and taking the density of granite as 2,700 kg/m^3, and the moment of inertia of a solid granite sphere of mass 2.5 metric tons is 360 kg m^2.

The only problem here is that he is looking for concepts in linear motion while the kugel (that's what such a ball balanced on a water cushion is called) is a rotational system.  He should be looking for rotational velocity, acceleration, torque (instead of force) and rotational inertia.  While the concepts are similar and analogous, they are not the same.  Measuring a mass for a linear system is simple; computing the rotational mass of the kugel, or a million other possible rotating shapes, is a lot harder, usually requiring calculus, unless someone did the work for you and put it into a CRC book.

1. an elevator traveling upwards at a constant velocity of, say, 5m/s - it is in force equilibrium ie: the force pulling the up cable is equal to the weight of the elevator.
2. an elevator hanging with no velocity (0m/s) - it is also in force equilibrium ie: the force pulling the up cable is equal to the weight of the elevator.
.
How does one get from case 2 to case 1?.... well you have to apply a little more force to the up cable start accelerating the elevator and raising its velocity....right?...... and then lower the force to reach equilibrium between up cable and weight at 5m/s... you are in essence breaking the inertia of the elevator.
.
Such a simple concept - yet what is amazing is that we cannot measure that inertia. We know it exists - but we can't measure it. Einstein even gave it a try and he couldn't come up with a formula.....HAS VERITASIUM FOUND THE FORMULA????
.
As a weird concept on how this affects us every day: Car safety belts are actually called "Inertia Belts" and use the concept of inertia to lock the safety belt. ie: we know how it works, we use it for the safety of people in cars.... but we don't know how to measure it..... shame on us ;-)

Just to make it clear, inertia is not an actual property of the body, but mass is. It just wants to say that in the equation F=ma , if you apply certain F but the mass is gigantic, acceleration is going to get small, i.e. mass=measurement of resistance to acceleration, the more mass you have, the less acceleration you are going to get from the same force. Inertia describes the phenomenon that acceleration, change in velocity in respect to time get's small as mass gets large. to make it intuitively easier to comprehend, it's usually stated: Inertia is property of matter to resist change; but you  can see from this that inertia is basically mass, but its physically more correct to call that property mass, not inertia.

It is often the case that younger children are more likely to correctly make explanations such as this.. generally it is their language and mathematical skill that stops them from being able to articulate these ideas. The reason (as far as I can tell) is because they have fewer experiences of the world and therefore fewer misconceptions going in.. It is therefore important to time Physics concepts correctly. If the explanation requires lots of mathematics, abstract concepts or complex language to explain then just DON'T... do something else. Forces and Motion are an example of concepts that can be explored relatively young and don't require them to believe in invisible things (such as air particles!) Get them exploring mechanics, mechanical advantage, pulleys and weights, floating and sinking, springs and pendulums... don't worry too much if they cannot get the difference between Newtons 3 laws or remember the words Kinetic and Potential energy... so long as they can differentiate between the concepts then this is the firmest foundation for future success in the Physical sciences.

When you talk of the resistance to change momentum, you're talking about inertial mass. Mass and energy are the same, said Einstein. If you get more kinetic energy, you get more mass. Obviously, this is only experimentally measureable when you're around 0.1 times the speed of light, or around 675 million Mi/h, pretty fast, huh?

Rest mass in unaffected by speed, but inertial mass is affected by the change of energy in an object, in this case, speed. Look for special relativity for more information. For an object with a rest mass 'm' and a velocity 'v', the inertial mass 'M' looks like this: M = γ*m, where γ = 1/(1-v^2/c^2)^(1/2). Mass increases with speed.

@1gummyipod1 let's say a treadmill goes 850km/h - if you hold an object 'stationary' above it, that object would have to be travelling at an airspeed of 850km/h (since the air moves along with the treadmill). That's as fast as the plane can fly - so it doesn't really matter if you regard the plane as stationary and the Earth as moving below or the Earth as stationary and the plane as moving at 850 km/h over it.

@1veritasium But if the earth is traveling opposite to you, and you are cruising at your air speed, why doesn't the spin of the earth decrease your travel time?  For instance on a treadmill, if I were to hold an object above it, and the object was not moving, but the treadmill was, relative to the treadmill the object moved (because the surface it was above did), why is it that, if an airplane remains in the earth's atmosphere, the same thing doesn't happen (the earth's surface also moves)?

@1gummyipod1 Before you take off, the plane is going at the same speed as Earth's surface (and so is the atmosphere). Now after take off, the plane speeds up to its cruising air speed, usually around 850 km/h relative to the air. But since the air is moving at the same speed as the Earth, it doesn't matter if you're travelling west or east, your velocity _relative to Earth's surface_ is the same in both directions.
